docs.text: C -lang B ehaviour T able Documenting various compiler implementations' of unspecified behaviour in C programs This website contains code examples of C code that uses unspecified C language features that behave in different ways depending on the compiler used and possibly the flags used during compilation as well. Sections There are several main sections that look at parts of the C specification which are unspecified. The main sections are listed below from wherein you can find more convoluted examples. Functions List initializers

docs.text: L1 : List initializer evaluation ordering Description The order in which the elements in a list initializer are executed is unspeccified. Here we will be looking at a relatively simple example (akin to the same level as that of F1 ) in terms of possible ordering outcomes. int result[2] = {counter(), counter()}; The execution can change which value we have at result[0] and result[1] ; this is a simple example as there are only two permutations. Implicit version The implicit version of what we will be analysing is related to the following: #include<assert.h> #include<stdio.h> /* Global data */ int count = 0; /* Counting function */ int counter() { count++; return count; } int main() { /** * Calculate the array * * Ex1: {1, 2} * Ex2: {2, 1} */ int result[2] = {counter(), counter()}; printf("[%d, %d]\n", result[0], result[1]); } Results of behaviour Here we document the behaviour of various C compiler implementations on the above code and which arguments (further variations) were used and lastly the outcome. You can reproduce the below by checking out the L1 tests . docs.text: The order in which the elements in a list initializer are executed is unspeccified. Here we will be looking at a relatively simple example (akin to the same level as that of F1 ) in terms of possible ordering outcomes. int result[2] = {counter(), counter()}; The execution can change which value we have at result[0] and result[1] ; this is a simple example as there are only two permutations.

docs.title: Results of behaviour

docs.text: Unwound versions that can be used for benchmarking. Every compiler and options combination that has a certain obersavtion is matched below:
docs.title: Explicit versions

docs.text: #include<assert.h> #include<stdio.h> /* Global data */ int count = 0; /* Counting function */ int counter() { count++; return count; } int main() { int res1_val = counter(); int res2_val = counter(); int result[2] = {res1_val, res2_val}; assert(result[0] == 1); assert(result[1] == 2); }
docs.title: left-to-right execution ordering

docs.text: F1 : Function Call Evaluation ordering Description The order in which the arguments to a function is evaluated is unspeccified. Here we will be looking at a piece of code which results in different outcomes depending on the order in which these funtions are executed by using globally shared state with funcitons senstiive to that. int result = f(counter(), counter()); F1 is the most basic of the tests being done, there are only two ways the function call to f could be evaluated (argument-wise) and the function being used to generate the argument expressions is the same function; counter() . Implicit version The implicit version of what we will be analysing is related to the following: #include<assert.h> #include<stdio.h> int globalCounter = 0; int counter() { globalCounter++; return globalCounter; } int f(int x1, int x2) { return (x1*2)+x2; } int main() { int result = f(counter(), counter()); printf("%d\n", result); } Results of behaviour Here we document the behaviour of various C compiler implementations on the above code and which arguments (further variations) were used and lastly the outcome. You can reproduce the below by checking out the F1 tests . docs.title: F1

docs.text: The order in which the arguments to a function is evaluated is unspeccified. Here we will be looking at a piece of code which results in different outcomes depending on the order in which these funtions are executed by using globally shared state with funcitons senstiive to that. int result = f(counter(), counter()); F1 is the most basic of the tests being done, there are only two ways the function call to f could be evaluated (argument-wise) and the function being used to generate the argument expressions is the same function; counter() .
docs.title: Description

docs.text: The implicit version of what we will be analysing is related to the following: #include<assert.h> #include<stdio.h> int globalCounter = 0; int counter() { globalCounter++; return globalCounter; } int f(int x1, int x2) { return (x1*2)+x2; } int main() { int result = f(counter(), counter()); printf("%d\n", result); }
docs.title: Implicit version

docs.text: Here we document the behaviour of various C compiler implementations on the above code and which arguments (further variations) were used and lastly the outcome. You can reproduce the below by checking out the F1 tests .

docs.text: F2 : Function Call Evaluation ordering (3 args) Description The order in which the arguments to a function is evaluated is unspeccified. Here we will be looking at a piece of code which results in different outcomes depending on the order in which these funtions are executed by using globally shared state with funcitons senstiive to that. int result = f(counter(), counter(), counter()); F2 is simply F1 but with three arguments. Implicit version The implicit version of what we will be analysing is related to the following: #include<assert.h> #include<stdio.h> int globalCounter = 0; int counter() { globalCounter++; return globalCounter; } int f(int x1, int x2, int x3) { return (x1*2)+x2+x3*3; } int main() { /** * 1,2,3 => (1*2)+2+3*3 => 13 * 3,2,1 => (3*2)+2+1*3 => 11 */ int result = f(counter(), counter(), counter()); printf("%d\n", result); } Results of behaviour Here we document the behaviour of various C compiler implementations on the above code and which arguments (further variations) were used and lastly the outcome. You can reproduce the below by checking out the F2 tests . Every compiler and options combination that has a certain obersavtion is matched below: right-to-left execution ordering #include<assert.h> #include<stdio.h> int globalCounter = 0; int counter() { globalCounter++; return globalCounter; } int f(int x1, int x2, int x3) { return (x1*2)+x2+x3*3; } int main() { /** * 1,2,3 => (1*2)+2+3*3 => 13 * 3,2,1 => (3*2)+2+1*3 => 11 */ int subRes1 = counter(); int subRes2 = counter(); int subRes3 = counter(); int result = f(subRes3, subRes2, subRes1); assert(result == 11); } left-to-right execution ordering #include<assert.h> #include<stdio.h> int globalCounter = 0; int counter() { globalCounter++; return globalCounter; } int f(int x1, int x2, int x3) { return (x1*2)+x2+x3*3; } int main() { /** * 1,2,3 => (1*2)+2+3*3 => 13 * 3,2,1 => (3*2)+2+1*3 => 11 */ int subRes1 = counter(); int subRes2 = counter(); int subRes3 = counter(); int result = f(subRes1, subRes2, subRes3); assert(result == 13); }

docs.text: Unwound versions that can be used for benchmarking. Every compiler and options combination that has a certain obersavtion is matched below:
docs.title: Explicit versions

docs.text: #include<assert.h> #include<stdio.h> int globalCounter = 0; int counter() { globalCounter++; return globalCounter; } int f(int x1, int x2, int x3) { return (x1*2)+x2+x3*3; } int main() { /** * 1,2,3 => (1*2)+2+3*3 => 13 * 3,2,1 => (3*2)+2+1*3 => 11 */ int subRes1 = counter(); int subRes2 = counter(); int subRes3 = counter(); int result = f(subRes3, subRes2, subRes1); assert(result == 11); }
docs.title: right-to-left execution ordering

docs.text: #include<assert.h> #include<stdio.h> int globalCounter = 0; int counter() { globalCounter++; return globalCounter; } int f(int x1, int x2, int x3) { return (x1*2)+x2+x3*3; } int main() { /** * 1,2,3 => (1*2)+2+3*3 => 13 * 3,2,1 => (3*2)+2+1*3 => 11 */ int subRes1 = counter(); int subRes2 = counter(); int subRes3 = counter(); int result = f(subRes1, subRes2, subRes3); assert(result == 13); }
docs.title: left-to-right execution ordering

docs.text: Lists What is this section about? This section is aimed at documenting the behaviour of so called "list initialzers" in C. This is a language feature ( TODO : Find out when this was added (which specificaiton version)) which allows one to initialize the elements of an array as part of the array declaration. An example may be the following: /** * Initialize an array to have the values of [0, 1, 2]: */ int array[3] = {0, 1, 2}; Rules The example provided above is a very basic example and the behaviour of it is the same across implementations for the simple reason that the values used to initialize it, namely 0 , 1 and 2 , require no further evaluation. Where the focus of this section comes in is when these expressions are more complex, specifically with expressions that have side-effects and where those side-effects effect the returned value of the evaluation. We will therefore be looking therefore at code that is more along the lines of the following: /** * Initialize the array to have the first element be the returned value of `f()` * and the second element the returned value of `g()` */ int array[2] = {f(), g()}; Unspecified behaviour One would assume that the order of evaluation would be to call f() then g() and have those returned values respectively saved into the positions, array[0] and array[1] . The latter happens, but the former (the order of calls) is unspecified and the order of execution is up to the compiler implementer. Table of behaviour This section contains several tables relating to how a specific snippet of C code, which makes use of this undeterminism, behaves. 2-argument function call
